Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Wavelet-Based Representations for Hyperspectral Data Processing and Interpretation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Hyperspectral imaging systems play an important role in scientific research, especially in planetary and terrestrial geology, environmental monitoring, military and security surveillance, and mineralogy. With current advances in imaging systems technology, large datasets at higher resolutions are being produced and research on automated analysis of these datasets is becoming critical. The goal of this project is to formulate mathematical models for hyperspectral datasets that capture the types of structure commonly identified by practitioners as informative and leveraged semantically in existing ad-hoc methods. The focus is on models based on wavelet representations for spectral signatures in order to provide features that represent the desired multiscale structural information. The features will leverage the wavelet's multiscale time-frequency analysis properties, and will be tested on several labeling, classification, and retrieval problems from a broad range of application areas that are expected to attract underrepresented groups in engineering. This proposal is centered on the application of the proposed models to hyperspectral signal processing and machine learning. The overall goal is to formulate and study new geometric signal models for high-dimensional data and new performance metrics for parameter estimation to be leveraged by new computationally feasible estimation algorithms that (i) are amenable to compressive signal processing due to the use of geometric structure to capture relevant signal information and (ii) overcome the performance shortcomings observed in existing approaches. The formulation of a semantic model for spectral signatures is expected to increase the acceptance of universal representations in applications where processes driven by ad-hoc rules are commonplace. The project broadens participation of underrepresented groups by considering applications areas that have the potential to appeal to diverse communities and constituencies in order to attract interest from a diverse class of populations underrepresented in engineering. Student researchers will be exposed to collaborators from a diverse set of scientific backgrounds and cultures. Opportunities for undergraduate research and high-school teacher research experience will be offered in this project with a particular emphasis on venues serving groups underrepresented in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to formulate mathematical models for hyperspectral datasets that capture the types of structure commonly identified by practitioners as informative and leveraged semantically in existing ad-hoc methods. We focused on models based on wavelet representations for spectral signatures in order to provide features that represent the desired multiscale structural information and leverage the wavelet’s time-frequency analysis properties. We pursued several avenues of research during the duration of this project, as detailed below.

 

1. Formulation of semantics from statistical models for hyperspectral signatures: We introduced the use of non-homogeneous hidden Markov chains for wavelet coefficients of hyperspectral signatures that provide a representation of the information contained in a hyperspectral dataset. Carefully obtained features from the wavelet model can capture scientifically meaningful information on the spectral signatures for the minerals under study. The proposed model makes use of the full structural information of hyperspectral signals and interprets unknown information solely based on training data. We identified several semantic features that can be obtained from our models and that were demonstrated to be highly relevant to several problems in hyperspectral image processing, such as signature classification, band selection, and semi-supervised endmember unmixing.

2. Performance of spectral unmixing algorithms under nonlinearities: Many spectral unmixing algorithms rely on the notion of a linear mixing process, where the observed spectrum is a linear convex combination of the spectra of the endmembers. In practice, however, the physics of the observation process yield a nonlinear relationship between the individual endmember signatures and that of the mixture, and the community is aware of the potential loss in performance when the unmixing algorithm assumes a linear mixture, e.g., non-negative sparse regression. We developed a mathematically tractable prediction of unmixing performance using sparse approximations based on our proposed positive exact recovery coefficient (PERC) as a measure of the geometry of the underlying spectrum model. We verified the performance of our guarantees on synthetic and experimental dataset involving nonlinear mixtures.

3. Characterization of datasets generated by intimate mixing models: In order to identify the complications that arise in the analysis of high-dimensional mineral mixture dataset statistics, we have developed low-rank neighborhood-based data models to characterize the peculiarly non-linear geometrical structure of such datasets in an unsupervised fashion. Additionally, we proposed Joint Manifold Clustering and Embedding (JMCE), an unmixing algorithm that leverages the non-linear geometrical structure (adjoining manifolds) of spectral datasets involving multiple mixtures and mild nuisances to perform simultaneous classification and embedding of the dataset. The characterization and algorithm performance were verified using real-world measured spectra and simulated reflectance datasets generated from mixtures of several minerals.

4. Real-World Statistical Modeling of Hyperspectral Data: One of the main limitations we found during this project is the difficulty of training generalizable high-dimensional statistical models from limited numbers of samples. We developed a large set of mineral mixture samples to validate our models in collaboration with Prof. M. D. Dyar (Mount Holyoke College). We also involved multiple NSF REU students to (i) perform mineral sample collection, curation, and cataloguing; (ii) implement of more realistic physical models for spectral variability to be used in the generation of synthetic signature samples; (iii) develop computationally efficient implementations of our algorithms for statistical model training and sample labeling. The results of these efforts have produced a database and toolbox (the latter still under development) for spectral signature classification problems.
